metadata.title: Efficient polysulfide blocker from conductive niobium nitride@graphene for Li-S batteries

(e) The corresponding areal capacity performance of the cells with sulfur loadings of 6.1 and 10.8 mg cm−2 (0.1 C). Fig 6 Efficient polysulfide blocker from conductive niobium nitride@graphene for Li-S batteries Huifa Shi a c 1 Zhenhua Sun b 1 Wei Lv a ⁎ Shujie Xiao a c Huicong Yang b Ying Shi b Ke Chen b Shaogang Tianjin 300072, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Lithium sulfur batteries are one of the most promising alternative electrochemical systems, but their practical applications are largely hindered by the serious shuttling problems and sluggish redox kinetics. Here, the conductive and polar niobium nitride (NbN) is in-situ introduced onto graphene with ultra-small size and high dispersion, and their composite is used to construct an efficient lithium polysulfide blocking layer. The graphene helps to construct highly conductive pathways, and niobium nitride serves as the sulfiphilic sites to chemically adsorb the migrating lithium polysulfides and catalyze their redox conversion. Hence, the cells with the NbN/G interlayers exhibit a long cycle life with a lower capacity decay of 0.096%/cycle at 1 C for 300 cycles and high rate capability of 937 mAh g−1 at 2 C. Further coupling with a sulfur/carbon nanofiber electrode, the cell with an ultra-high sulfur loading of 10.8 mg cm−2 delivers an areal capacity of 12.5 mAh cm−2 at 0.1 C. Graphical abstract Ultra-small niobium nitride is introduced into the graphene interlayer with good dispersibility, which acts as sulfiphilic sites to immobilize polysulfides and catalyze their conversion. This polysulfide-blocking shield ensures excellent electrochemical performance of lithium sulfur batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Niobium nitride Chemical adsorption Catalytic effect High loading 1 Introduction The emergency and rapid development of the portable electronics and electric vehicles boost demand in the mobile energy storage systems with high energy density and long life. However, the commercially available lithium-ion batteries, based on insertion cathode materials and graphite anode, gradually approach ceiling values and could not meet those requirements [1–3]. Consequently, exploring alternative energy storage systems is looming. Composed of a sulfur/carbon cathode, a lithium metal anode and an organic electrolyte, lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries are one of the most competitive alternatives in the coming decades, because they have a high theoretical specific capacity of 1675 mAh g−1, a high theoretical energy density (2500 Wh kg−1 and 2800 Wh L−1) and cost-effectiveness [4,5]. In spite of these advantages, the rapid capacity fading, short cycle life and the inefficient utilization of sulfur greatly prevent the commercialization of Li-S batteries [4]. These challenging obstacles are mainly attributed to low electronic and ionic conductivities of sulfur, shuttling of the produced lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and safety concerns from lithium metal anode, etc. [1,6]. To overcome these problems, varieties of nanocarbon materials are designed to accommodate sulfur [7], such as hollow spheres [8], nanofibers [9,10] and three dimensional architectures [11,12], providing a larger sulfur storage space. However, these methods still produce unsatisfactory electrochemical results. In 2012, Manthiram's group [13] inserted a microporous carbon paper between the separator and the sulfur cathode, which simultaneously functioned as an upper current collector and a LiPS blocker. As predicted, this architecture substantially optimized the cycle performance and rate capability, especially for the electrodes with high sulfur loadings and high sulfur contents. This research enlightens the application of interlayer for advanced Li-S batteries, and lots of nanocarbons are explored, including graphene [14], carbon nanotubes [15] and carbon nanofibers [16]. However, only the a physical barrier can not meet the requirements for a longer cycle life and higher discharge capacity, because the non-polar nature of the carbon surface can not immobilize the soluble LiPSs. On account of a stronger chemical interaction between transition metal compounds and LiPSs [17,18], introducing polar nanoparticles into the carbon-based interlayers would contribute to a better electrochemical stability [19]. As one of the transition metal nitrides, niobium nitride (NbN) has excellent electric conductivity, polar surface and good chemical stability at room temperature [20,21], and also is a promising superconductor at the ultra-low temperature [22]. In this work, NbN nanoparticles with ultra-small size are in-situ grown onto the surface of graphene through a polyol-mediated solvothermal reaction followed by annealing under ammonia atmosphere [23,24]. The NbN/G composite obtained is filtrated onto the commercial separator and used an interlayer to suppress the shutting behaviors. This efficient interlayer possesses following advantages: (1) The graphene can physically block LiPS diffusion and construct highly efficient conductive pathways; (2) the polar NbN not only acts as chemical reservoirs to adsorb the diffused LiPSs, but also accelerate the redox reaction of LiPSs; (3) the ultra-small size and the good dispersibility of NbN particles create more electroactive sites to interact with the LiPSs and the close contact between NbN and graphene facilitate the fast electron transport and LiPS transformation at the interface. With the synergistic effect of graphene and NbN nanoparticles, the sulfur cathode with a NbN/G@PP separator delivers a higher cyclic stability with a residual capacity of 768 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 1 C, and better rate capability of 937 mAh g−1 at 2 C. Furthermore, coupling with a sulfur/carbon nanofiber cathode with a sulfur loading of 10.8 mg cm−2, the cell using a NbN/G@PP separator exhibits an ultra-high areal capacity of 12.5 mAh cm−2 at 0.1 C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of NbN/G composite The graphene oxide (GO) solution was prepared via water electrolytic oxidation of graphite [25]. The GO powder was obtained by freeze-drying the solution to remove the water. Then 200 mg GO was well-dispersed in 80 mL ethylene glycol (EG) using a strong tip ultrasonication (200 W, 30 min). In addition, 40 mg niobium chloride (NbCl5) was dissolved into 30 mL EG by magnetic stirring. Then, the NbCl5 solution was added into the GO solution dropwise, and the mixed solution was stirred for another 1 h. Then, the mixed solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and a following solvothermal reaction process (180 °C, 24 h) was conducted to produce Nb2O5/reduced GO [23]. After being washed with de-ionized water and freeze-dried, the sample was subjected to a heat treatment of 700 °C for 4 h under ammonia atmosphere to produce the NbN/G. Graphene sample was synthesized by the same procedure without adding NbCl5. 2.2 Fabrication of the modified separator NbN/G powder (16 mg) was dispersed in the ethanol (80 mL) under strong ultra-sonication for 30 min, and the dispersed solution of 20 mL was filtered onto a commercial Celgard 2400 separator, which was denoted as NbN/G@PP [26]. After drying at 60 °C in a vacuum oven, the NbN/G@PP was cut into a circular pellet with a diameter of 19 mm and an areal loading of 0.28 mg cm−2. Then, the modified separator was directly to fabricate a cell. The graphene modified separator (G@PP) with the same mass loading was fabricated following the same procedure as above. 2.3 Materials characterization Scanning electron microscopes (SEM, FEI Nova NanoSEM 430, 15 kV) and transmission electron microscopes (TEM, Tecnai F20, 200 kV) were used to observe the morphology and structure of the prepared materials. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns was collected using a Rigaku diffractometer using Cu K α radiation at room temperature. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves was obtained using a NETZSCH STA 449 C thermo-balance in air from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. An ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher) instrument with a monochromated Al K α radiation was used to conduct X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. A four-point probe instrument (RTS-9, PROBES TECH) were performed to measure the electrical conductivities of the different interlayers which were filtrated onto the PP separator. X-ray microtomography (XRM) characterization was conducted using a Versa XRM-500 desktop system with a microfocus tube and the acceleration voltage was 50 kV. 2.4 Adsorption test of NbN/G and graphene for lipss To test the LiPS adsorption ability of NbN/G and graphene, the Li2S6 solution was first prepared by adding stoichiometric amounts of sulfur and lithium sulfide in the mixed solvent of DME/DOL (1:1, vol%). Magnetic stirring was conducted at 60 °C in the Ar-filled glove box until the powders were total dissolved. Subsequently, the concentration of Li2S6 solution was diluted to 1 mM. 20 mg NbN/G or graphene was added into 1 mM Li2S6 solution of 5 ml. Digital photos were taken before and after adsorption [27]. Finally, the UV–vis spectra were performed to verify the residual concentration of Li2S6 solution [28,29]. 2.5 Assembly and evaluation of symmetric electrochemical cells The NbN/G and PVDF were mixed with a weight ratio of 8:2 and grinded in NMP. The slurry was blade coated onto an aluminum foil. After dried at 60 °C for 12 h, the electrodes were punched into circular pellets of 12 mm. The areal loading of the host materials is 0.5 mg cm−2. To assembly the symmetrical cells, two identical electrodes were used as both the working electrode and the counter electrode, respectively. 15 µL Li2S6 solution (0.5 M) with 1 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 additive was added into the cell as the electrolyte. The CV profiles were recorded at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 in a voltage window of −0.8 V ~ +0.8 V using a VSP-300 multichannel work station [30]. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements The sulfur and Super P mixtures (2:1, w/w) were obtained after melt-diffusion at 155 °C for 12 h. Then, the sulfur cathode was fabricated by sulfur/Super P mixture and polyvinylidene fluoride (9:1, w/w) in 1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, and the slurry was blade coated onto a carbon-coated aluminum foil. A phase inversion method reported [30] was used to avoid the crack on drying. After being dried at 60 °C for 12 h, the sulfur cathode was cut into circular pellets with a diameter of 12 mm. The sulfur content in the cathode is 60 wt% and the sulfur areal loading is 1–1.5 mg cm−2. Besides, to prepare the sulfur/carbon nanofiber (S/CNF) electrodes for assembling the cells with higher sulfur loadings of 6.1 mg cm−2 and 10.8 mg cm−2, freestanding carbon nanofiber pellets were obtained from freeze-drying and carbonization (1000 °C, 2 h) of commercial bacterial cellulose hydrogels [31]. The sulfur was melt-diffused into the carbon networks at 155 °C for 12 h and the sulfur content is 60 wt% in the electrode. When the mass of interlayer is taken into consideration, the content is still up to 56 wt% (6.1 mg cm−2) and 58 wt% (10.8 mg cm−2), respectively. Electrochemical studies were carried out using 2025-type coin cells, and lithium metal was used as the anode. PP, G@PP and NbN/G@PP were selected as the separators, respectively. A solution with 1 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 in a DOL/DME (1:1 v/v) mixture was prepared and used as the electrolyte. To fully wet the interlayer, an excess electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 35 µl mg−1 is chosen for all assembled cells [32]. Electrochemical cycle stability and rate capability were tested using a LAND instrument and the voltage range is 1.7~2.8 V. A VSP-300 multichannel workstation was used to measure the cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles. 3 Results and discussion To synthesize the NbN/G composite, a Nb2O5/rGO composite was first obtained through a solvothermal method reported previously [23], and a subsequent nitriding process was conducted to produce the NbN/G. The GO provides lots of sites for uniformly dispersing and anchoring the nanoparticles with small sizes and the graphene obtained after the reduction works as a conductive network for fast electron transport [33,34]. The NbN/G was filtrated onto a commercial separator and work as a LiPS blocking layer in the cell configuration, as shown in the Fig. 1 (a, b). During discharge/charge process, the polar and conductive NbN nanoparticles can chemically adsorb the diffused LiPSs and promote their redox transformation to the lithium sulfide or sulfur, as displayed in Fig. 1(c). The shutting problem is inhibited and the utilization of active materials is greatly improved consequently. Fig. 2 (a) clearly displays the SEM image of the NbN/G as obtained. The corrugated sheets exhibit a unstacked morphology, facilitating the subsequent dispersion. Fig. 2(b) clearly displays the TEM image of NbN/G. The NbN nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the graphene. As revealed in the Fig. 2(c), the nanoparticles have a size of 5~10 nm and are attached onto the graphene support tightly, which can enhance the fast electron transfer in the interface. The lattice fringes of 0.25 and 0.21 nm are attributed to (111) and (200) planes of cubic-phase NbN. Furthermore, the STEM images and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy maps of carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O) and niobium (Nb) are clearly observed in the Fig 2(d–h) and all of them display a similar distribution. Besides, A STEM image with a higher magnification in Fig. S1 shows the element Nb perfectly overlaps with the nanoparticles, further indicating the nanoparticles are the niobium compound. The Fig. 2(i) discloses the XRD patterns of NbN/G and graphene. In addition to the typical carbon peaks at 26° and 43°, the rest of the diffraction peaks can be indexed as NbN (JCPDS no. 38–1155). The content of NbN is 15.6%, which is determined via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in air. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface areas of graphene and NbN/G are 203 m2 g−1 and 182 m2 g−1, respectively. Comparing to the carbon materials, the transition metal compounds particles show stronger affinity for LiPSs because of their polar surface. In here, a visual discrimination was conducted to prove the adsorbability of NbN/G and graphene to Li2S6 (Fig. 3 (a, b)). After resting for 12 h, the color of LiPS solution with graphene added become a little lighter, while the solution with NbN/G nearly changes to colorless [35]. This clear difference indicates that the NbN nanoparticles can help trap the soluble LiPSs in the electrolyte and inhibit their uncontrollable diffusion. Moreover, UV–vis analysis (Fig. 3c) was performed to analyze the concentration of the supernatant solutions after a complete adsorption. The results demonstrate that the peak intensity of the solution with NbN/G decrease more than that with graphene, which means much more Li2S6 molecules are adsorbed onto the surface of NbN/G [36]. A deeper investigation about the interaction between NbN and LiPSs is performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). After being soaked in the Li2S6 solution and dried, a typical S 2p peak occurs in addition to the O 1s, N 1s, C 1s and Nb 3d, as exhibited in the Fig. 3(d). In Fig. 3(e), the XPS fine Nb 3d spectrum of NbN/G reveals the existence of Nb−N, Nb−N−O and Nb−O bonds. After adsorbing Li2S6, two new peaks at 204.3 and 206.3 eV occur (Fig. 3f), which verifies the formation of strong Nb-S bonds [21]. The NbN/G powder was fully dispersed in the ethanol and then filtrated onto a commercial separator. The prepared NbN/G modified separator (Fig. 4 a) is denoted as NbN/G@PP, and directly used to assemble a Li-S battery. The top-view image of the PP separator shows a porous appearance (Fig. 4b). After coated with NbN/G, a flat blocking film composed of the sheets are formed (Fig. 4c). Fig. 4(d) shows a typical cross-sectional image of NbN/G interlayer, which displays a thickness of 22 µm. The corresponding elemental map of Nb indicates a uniform distribution of element Nb in whole NbN/G layer (Fig. 4e). A cross-sectional XRM image of NbN/G interlayer displays a similar thickness of 25 µm, which is thinner and denser than the graphene interlayer of 40 µm (Fig. S2b) [37,38]. The electrolyte wettability on the PP and NbN/G@PP separators was investigated by the electrolyte contact angle. As displayed in the Fig. S3, the electrolyte contact angle on the surface of NbN/G@PP is smaller than those of the G@PP separator and the commercial PP separator. The smaller electrolyte contact angle indicates a lower surface tension at the interface, which facilitates a faster penetration and a better preservation of added electrolyte in the NbN/G@PP separator. The electrical conductivities of the prepared NbN/G layer and graphene layer are 81.7 S m−1 and 70.5 S m−1 measured by a four-point probe instrument. The high conductivity helps a fast electron transport for the LiPS redox reactions. Finally, the as-prepared NbN/G@PP separator was still intact when bended, folded and bended in the electrolyte after being soaked in the electrolyte for 6 h, indicating its mechanical robustness [39], as shown in the Fig. 4(f–i). To evaluate the cells with different separators, a series of electrochemical tests were conducted. Fig. 5 (a) displays the CV curves of cells with different separators. The cathodic peaks are attributed to the reduction of sulfur to long-chain Li2S x (4 ≤ x < 8) and then to short-chain Li2S2/Li2S. In the charge process, the two anodic peaks correspond to the reversible oxidation of discharge products Li2S2/Li2S back to long-chain LiPSs and to sulfur [40,41]. The cell using NbN/G separator demonstrates a shorter voltage polarization and larger redox current density, which means a faster redox reaction kinetics [42,43]. Besides, Fig. S4 shows the first four CV curves of the cell with a NbN/G interlayer. The CV curves almost overlap, indicating good reversibility and stability of the cells. The better electrochemical kinetics are further verified by the symmetric cells using two identical NbN/G@Al or G@Al electrodes without sulfur as the working and counter electrodes. The electrolyte containing 0.5 M Li2S6 is added onto the separator. The polarization CV curve of NbN/G is shown in the Fig. 5(b) and displays a higher reduction/oxidation current density than that of graphene, indicating a catalytic effect of NbN on the LiPS transformation in the solid/liquid interface [44]. Rate capabilities of cells with different separators are evaluated and shown in the Fig. 5(c). The cell with the NbN/G@PP separator delivers superior discharge capacities of 1394, 1172, 1090, 1023 and 937 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, respectively. In contrast, the cells with G@PP and PP separators exhibit inferior rate performance. The corresponding charge/discharge voltage profiles are displayed in the Fig. 5(d). Even at 2 C, the profiles still exhibit two obvious discharge plateaus and charge plateaus, indicating the rapid redox reactions. Cycling stability is investigated at 1 C, the cell with a NbN/G separator exhibits a low capacity decay of 0.096%/cycle for 300 cycles. Meanwhile, the cell with a NbN/G separator shows an initial discharge capacity of 1079 mAh g−1 and a residual discharge capacity of 768 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles, which is clearly higher than the cells with G@PP and PP separators. Besides, a longer cycle performance at 2 C was also shown in the Fig. S5, which also exhibits a stable cycle performance and a residual capacity of 452 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles. The better cycle stability and rate capability clearly demonstrate that the embedded NbN nanparticles on the graphene not only substantially adsorb the diffused LiPSs to inhibit their shuttling behaviors, but also promote their fast redox conversion to sulfur or short-chain LiPSs [19,45,46]. The chemically adsorption and catalysis of NbN nanoparticles combined with the physical barriers of graphene contribute to the superior electrochemical performance. High sulfur loading, one of the important factors affecting the energy density, is essential for the viable Li-S batteries [47–49]. Hence, the cells with higher sulfur loadings using NbN/G@PP separators were tested and evaluated, and the electrochemical results are shown in the Fig. 6 . A freestanding carbon nanofiber film with an interconnected conductive network (Fig. S6) was prepared by the reported method [31] and used as the sulfur host. The sulfur was melt-diffused into the carbon networks, as exhibited in the Figs. 6(a) and S7. The CV curves of the cell with a sulfur loading of 6.1 mg cm−2 (Fig. 6b) display two obvious cathodic peaks and two anodic peaks, and the overlapped curves in the first 4 cycles indicate the good reversibility of the cells. Besides, even with sulfur loadings of 6.1 and 10.8 mg cm−2, the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves (Fig. 6c) of the cells still display two obvious discharge plateaus and charge plateaus, indicating the fast transformation and good reversibility of redox reactions. The cycle performance of the cells with sulfur loadings of 6.1 mg cm−2 and 10.8 mg cm−2 at 0.1 C are shown in the Fig. 6(d), which demonstrates good stability for 40 cycles. The initial discharge capacity of the cell with a sulfur loading of 10.8 mg cm−2 is 1156 mAh g−1, and the corresponding areal capacity is 12.5 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 6e). After cycling, the areal capacity is 8.8 mAh cm−2, which is far higher than that of the commercial Li-ion batteries (4 mAh cm−2) [50,51] and the most reported Li-S batteries [26,35], as shown in the Table S1. The high discharge capacity and good stability of the cells with high sulfur loadings are ascribed to the NbN/G@PP separator. Synergistic blocking effect from the graphene and polar NbN prevents the shuttling behaviors of the produced LiPSs and improve the utilization of active materials. 4 Conclusions In summary, the NbN/G is introduced into the Li-S batteries and used as the LiPS barrier layer. Benefiting from the highly conductive and polar nature and uniform dispersion, the in-situ grown NbN nanoparticles work as chemically binding sites and kinetically catalytic centers to immobilize the diffused LiPSs and accelerate their subsequent conversion. Besides, the graphene acts as a physical barrier and affords a fast electron transport for the redox reactions. As a result, Li-S batteries with a NbN/G interlayer exhibit a better cyclability with a low capacity decay 0.096%/cycle at 1 C for 300 cycles and remarkable rate performance (937 mAh g−1 at 2 C). Moreover, coupling with a S/CNF electrode, a high areal capacity of 12.5 mAh cm−2 at 0.1 C can be achieved. Our study presents a promising avenue to fabricate a Li-S battery with high performance. coredata.dc:description: Lithium sulfur batteries are one of the most promising alternative electrochemical systems, but their practical applications are largely hindered by the serious shuttling problems and sluggish redox kinetics. Here, the conductive and polar niobium nitride (NbN) is in-situ introduced onto graphene with ultra-small size and high dispersion, and their composite is used to construct an efficient lithium polysulfide blocking layer. The graphene helps to construct highly conductive pathways, and niobium nitride serves as the sulfiphilic sites to chemically adsorb the migrating lithium polysulfides and catalyze their redox conversion. Hence, the cells with the NbN/G interlayers exhibit a long cycle life with a lower capacity decay of 0.096%/cycle at 1 C for 300 cycles and high rate capability of 937 mAh g−1 at 2 C. Further coupling with a sulfur/carbon nanofiber electrode, the cell with an ultra-high sulfur loading of 10.8 mg cm−2 delivers an areal capacity of 12.5 mAh cm−2 at 0.1 C.

coredata.dc:title: Efficient polysulfide blocker from conductive niobium nitride@graphene for Li-S batteries
